displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: As of right now, yes. Doctor: Ok, I gotta do something about that. Doctor: So I can't believe so many people are willing to come in the week of Thanksgiving, but ok. Patient: Yeah. (pause) Healthcare Professional: Alright, so I'll make a copy of these and then when you're done treatment you can--or while they're ordering the drug, if you want to go over and make your appointments-- Patient: Go see Y__? Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: with as to sort of, why am I doing this? Patient: Alright. Okay. Doctor: Um. Other questions you guys have? Patient: No. Family Member: The, um, who is the, is it a Hospital B’s, um, clinical trial or is it a combination with another company or? Doctor: Um. So, the phase one Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: study is, uh, a pharmaceutical company Family Member: Okay. Doctor: that is developing this drug. Uh, so, they’re the ones that are behind it. Um. So, this, uh, Patient: Mmm. Doctor: That makes it easier. But we probably will need you to come in, and then they check, uh, blood tests one day just to see what the levels are, and, uh, what dose is the right amount of dose.

Patient: Yes. It is. It’s the same thing. Doctor: Yes. So I would say, uh, I think that’s not going to work. That would be my- Patient: Yeah. They don’t, they don’t, they don’t- Doctor: From what I know. From what I know about it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so this is what the compound is. It’s called, amygdalin. And this is, it has cyanide. There it is, cyanide. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer.

Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: And uh the study that we have, which we have open right now is called the Transformer Trial. It’s an acronym. You don’t need to remember that. We’ll give you information about that – to read it. Patient: I appreciate that, thanks. Doctor: It’s called the Transformer Trial because it was funded by a grant that was called the Transformative Impact Grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And so we applied for a grant at the Department of Defense, actually, DOD. And they have a program whereby they support prostate cancer studies. Patient: DOD? Doctor: Yeah, the DOD. Patient: Wow. Doctor: I know; a lot of people are surprised. And this was a grant where the DOD wanted to fund a project that would a small benefit or have a transformative benefit. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In other words a pretty huge benefit. And they were also looking for things that were paradigm shifts. In other words that runs against the grain. And so one of my colleagues from H___ applied for this grant. His name is Dr. ___. He was the mastermind behind this approach. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Um, that’s it. Doctor: Uh, last time you talked to C_ about your fatigue at the end of the day. Patient: Eh, just tired at the end, at the end, after working all day. Doctor: Any pain anywhere? Patient: No. Doctor: Any belly pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have bleeding, bruising? Patient: No. Doctor: And any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. Bowels are moving

Family Member: I think Patient: And I finished that last night. Doctor: And so did they give you something also for spasms? Patient: No. Doctor: So Oxybutynin. Family Member: Uh well yes, they did but he decided not to take that. Patient: Oh yeah, they said for pain, and I didn’t need that. Doctor: Well that’s for spasm, but they also give you medicine for pain, Hydro-per ; so you can take either of those two medicines. Doctor: So five milligrams Patient: What’s a spasm? Family Member: Spasm. Doctor: Uh your bladder. You feel a cramping down.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m changing all of that. Patient: Oh, you’re gonna change that? Doctor: Yes, yes. So, October fourth, you’ll just go to chemo directly, to the labs and chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then October twenty-fifth, you’ll see me and get chemo. Patient: Okay. Okay. So, just Doctor: Okay. You need the oxycodone and the walker. Patient: And the, uh, Xanax. Doctor: What is the third script? Patient: My Xanax. That’s it here. So, I’ll need, need that, right. Doctor: Let me see when I gave you the Xanax last. (Pause)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But I'll hear from you anything that says we got to rush to therapy make a decision right now that I just need to figure out. We are adding Aximun scans to our scanning facility but we don't do them now. Patient: Right. Doctor: So I need to do a little bit of legwork as to where I refer you to how I get it ordered. Can you ? Go to Add Order. And type in Aximun. Healthcare Professional: This one? Doctor: Uh… Healthcare Professional: That one? Doctor: I don’t think so. Healthcare Professional: this shows up.

Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia? Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right.

Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Can you repeat – uh, why -- are you saying that he could go on the next trial? Doctor: You could try a trial and see how you do – Patient: Right. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole – Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could not and just go straight to surgery, do the re-routing that we talked about last time – Patient: Right. Doctor: And do the study after. Either way, the comforting part is there is a potential next treatment that is – Patient: Okay. So, so how come I can’t do, do the pills and do the treatment, too? Can I do both? Doctor: No, no, no. You could the, you could do the pills.

Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you. Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones.

Family Member: The doctor didn’t even want to – he wouldn’t prescribe it, then he did prescribe it and we went to the pharmacy and they said we don’t carry it. Patient: But he directed us to an over-the-counter thing that worked really well. So that helped a lot. Doctor: It must have been scopolamine or something. Family Member: Yeah it was for anti-nausea. Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening. Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we actually have another study which may or may not be open in time which is a pill plus another pill. The pill is Patient: I’m available all day tomorrow. Doctor: Okay. I will have to work with the group to see what they can do to get that. Patient: Or or I can, I can be s - I can be wherever I need to be at like seven o’clock on Wednesday morning. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: Is it - That’s about what, a two hour deal? Doctor: Mm probably longer. I would just spend, I would just block off a half a day because they’re probably gonna put you in that happy place like when you get a colonoscopy happy place. Patient: I am awake during my colonoscopies. I go into twilight. Doctor: You’ll be in twilight, you’ll be in twilight. Patient: Just ‘cause I like to look at the – doctor uh. Doctor: Oh you’re like, you like to actually be awake.

Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine. Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay.

Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though?
